print_settings.Notes:: Print upside down with the holes for the tools face down on the print bed.

title: Tool Holder for Maker Select 3d Printer (Wanhao Duplicator I3)

description.text:
Tool holder created for the Monoprice Maker Select 3d printer. This should also work for the Wanhao Duplicator I3.

Tool holder prints in two separate parts that slide together with a dovetail fitting. The tool holder mounts to the two holes in the top of the control box.

Has a variety of holes to hold different tools. I designed it to hold print remover (palette knife), two allen wrenches, two screw drivers, two small files, pen, exacto knife, print glue, wire cutters, needle nose pliers, brass brush.

I printed the part with the tool holes face down on the print bed.

Printer:

Maker Select

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2mm - .3mm

Infill:

10%-20%

Notes:

Print upside down with the holes for the tools face down on the print bed.

Elementary school kids have been having trouble hooking up their Makey Makey during lessons, so I thought this case might help them out. Instead of hooking the alligator clips to the Makey Makey the clips can easily hook to wires looped through the holes on the front and side of the case. The front of the case has holes for Earth, Up, Down, Left, Right, Space, and Click. The side of the case has holes for W, A, S, D, F, and G. The case can also house the Makey Makey and all wires when transporting. To attach the lid to the case I used Rare Earth magnets.

The Lid file has been fixed so that the magnet holes don't go all the way to the end of the lid.

description.text:
So if you are not using OctoPrint served from a RaspberryPi to drive your 3D printers, you are missing out! It is absolutely the easiest and most convenient way to get the printer setting and code from your computer to the build plate!

I am in no way associated with this open source project or any of its contributors. I am simply an avid user and fan of this great tool.

It is easy to setup and even easier to use. Get OctoPrint here and support the cause here

Now, among the cooler features of the whole OctoPi experience it the support for a PiCam or webcam to monitor your progress in real-time live-stream and/or capture your prints in time-lapse video. Yes REALLY!

The only challenge for me was to find a convenient way to mount and position the camera. I found that for different prints I wanted new locations to capture the action. So the Flexible PiCam Mount was born.

Just print off the base mount of your choice and fix it wherever it works for you on your cabinet or printer (3M Command strips work great!), print off enough of the ball and socket joint to reach your target, and snap on the camera mount.

Here is the camera I use: Waveshare Raspberry Pi Camera with the infrared wings removed. It is a small and good-quality camera with adjustable focus. Plus, I added a longer camera ribbon to make it even easier.

Enjoy! and as always I love to hear your feedback.

Also, I want to thank Giufini. The ball join in this project is a remix of the BS_Joint from his project PCB Workstation with Articulated Arms.

Printer:

monoprice maker ultimate

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.15

Infill:

20%

Notes:

You may need supports if you print the ball and socket joints in the socket down orientation. This orientation give a slightly more snug fit to the resulting arm.

This little accessory is a earphone organizer meant to be carried in the pocket in order to prevent your sound blasters from being tangled up. Simply pinch one end of the cord in the little circular cut out at one end of the bone and wrap the remaining cable around the body. When the end of the cable is reached, use the other cutout on the opposite side of the bone to secure whatever is left. Then, put the Earbone in your pocket or a bag and you'll never have to worry about your earphones tangling!

Note: The organizer is hollow on the inside!

title: Miniature Tome Tutorial
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
NOTE

This is not my work, it's the work of Josh Williamson from the DM Scotty Craft's and Games (Note that link won't work unless you are a member) facebook page. I used this technique with my Frostgrave Treasure Tokens, and people asked me how to do the book who didn't have access. Josh graciously allowed me to repost his tutorial.

I've included the models used for my book token as well.

If you'd like to craft some itty bitty spellbooks just like these, follow the steps I've detailed in this album. Making the cover: cut a strip of thin cardstock (I used an old ceral box) as wide as you want your books tall. These are 1cm tall and the length is not important as it will be cut down in the next few steps. You can make your books taller or shorter, but it's best to do batches all the same size because it makes fitting the pages much easier. Here I'm folding over the cardstock, but leaving a bit at the end, sort of a loop. This will become the spine. I am really crimping down hard with smooth face pliers. I fold the slick side to the inside of the book because I thin kthe more rough side emparts better texture when dry brushing. Now the spine takes shape after squishing the bend down. I just press it against a hard surface and then use my finger nail to sort of etch lines across the spine. Your spines should look something like this right now. Trim one side to whatever looks proportional or will fit on your already made shelves. I have literally never measured for this step, just cut it to what looks good. Now cut the back cover to match the front. And now you have some empty naked books. If you aren't making a Tome with straps or bolts you can skip ahead to base painting your books. When I want to make a Tome or locked book, I cut a strip from the same ceral box. It is just wide enough to not curl. Any skinnier and it becomes too fragile in the next step. I think it's between 1 and 2 mm wide. Here I've pulled back the slick face of the cardstock, just to make the strap a little less thick than the rest of the book. Now I've cut a point into the strap, just for extra detail. Glue the pointed end down to one cover. Making bolts, or adornments, whatever you want to call these. I have sort of imagined that maybe they are emergency tie-downs for a book that otherwise only needs a single strap. Like, maybe the owner of the book knows that occasionaly the book needs to be put on lockdown and these points can be used to lash the book shut. Bolts cut and glued onto the front and back cover corners. After the glue has time to set on the strap and bolts, I go back over those bits with a 50/50 glue & water wash to reinforce the bond. I find tiny pieces like this have a tendency to split and flake off. Don't be surprised if your little bolts shed a layer or two of paper. Now's the time to decide how full or expanded you want your Tome to look. I like the semi-spread open look, so I have the book positioned as such. Now I bend the strap in the correct points to suit a book that is open to this degree. Here I've marked the excess end of the strap where it needs to be cut. After cutting the strap, the Tome is ready to move on. I see brown cardstock and want it painted black. No colors anymore, I want them to turn black. :D The slick surface will need a couple coats, but the rough side should take the paint really well. I cast Darkness on the books. A couple coats should be plenty. Highlight the edges of your book. Dry-brush your books. Add shiny details to your books. Ok, the party is over. This is where the fun stops. However tall you cut your cardstock for the books, cut some basic copy/print paper into strips about 1mm shorter than the covers. Like the covers, the pages should be excessively long at this stage. These strips are about 9mm by 3.5cm, but they could have been longer at this stage. The width of the strip is the important factor. Soak the pages in coffee. Maybe drink some coffee. I try to space the strips of paper so they aren't touching. Leave them in there long enough (5-15 minutes) that they are stained when you GENTLY remove them. I use a small wet paint brush to pick them up and transfer them into a glass cassarole baking dish. Anything like tweezers will tear them at this stage. Bake the wet paper strips in your oven until every strip has curled. I use a glass cassarole dish. I baked these at 350f and I think it took less than 10 minutes. After they've been in the oven for 3-5 minutes, just sit there and watch. It's fun! Maybe don't use the convection setting or the little strips will start flying around inside the oven. Now our pages have some color, they're more rigid, the edges are darker, and they smell yummy. Stack the strips up and cut them right down the middle. The cut ends won't have the darkened rough edge, so keep track of which end is the 'show' end. The arrows are pointing toward the edges I want to show. I've bundled a number of cut pages together with the 'show' ends even with each other. You need to decide how thick the book is at this point by adding more or fewer pages to the bundle. The next step calls for my secret sauce again, the 50/50 water & glue mix. I use this often enough for various things that I just keep a pre-mixed bottle on-hand. The bottle cap containts a pool of the water-glue. Dip the still excessively long pages into the water-glue. I hold them here long enough to let the paper absorb some of the solution. That's about right. Just let it dwell a bit. Squeeze out the excess water when you think the pages are tacky and not so much 'wet' anymore. The bundle will still feel sticky, like fresh glue, but it has been disperse through the paper. Now leave it in the clothespin to dry. When the pages dry they should look something like this. Fitting the pages to the book, the 'show' ends are inserted and a line marked to indicate where I need to cut. I don't cut right on the line, becase I want the pages to be a tiny bit recessed. The end with the pencil marks is trash. Gather up the pages that are now cut to finished size. The previous gluing may keep them together, but some or all could be loose now. Square them up again and smooth some glue along the spine side (opposite the 'show' edge). Place a strip of colored paper along the spine, cut to the page height. I try to pick a color that contrasts or compliments the book cover's color. After the glue has a chance to set a bit you can start wrapping the binding around the sides. I tack it down with 50/50 glue that I believe soaks into a bit of the paper for a better bond. Binding paper stiff and dry, things should look like this by now. When the glue has fully set, it's safe to flair the pages. Even if you want a locked-closed Tome, it's good to flair the pages excessively so they sort of push back against the covers. Put a little 50/50 glue inside the book to anchor the pages. Push the bundle of pages into the book cover. The slow setting time should allow you to make sure it's positioned correctly. Now's the time to lock up those nasty spells if you need a secured Tome. Just put a point of glue on the loose end of the strap, then lock it down. I use a toothpick to add drops of 50/50 glue to the pages near the spine to both better secure them from falling out, and to add more strength and stiffness to the book. After adding the 50/50 glue to the pages in the previous step, the book will have a tendency to swell open (if not already locked closed with a strap). I try to find just the right balance of weight to squish them closed while they dry so they are splayed open how I like. And you're done! That was slightly fewer than 50 steps. Please forgive me.

description.text:

This is meant to be installed in ceiling fixtures that typically use three set screws to hold the light cover. I needed one that was open for use with some Phillips HUE LED bulbs. I used PLA. description.text:
Even though there are MANY spool holders for your needs, this one solves a specific need for me. My dry box project used hangers and a rod to keep the spools supported. This works but it has a few problems. Sometimes the spools get jammed and changing one is just brown noise.

So, this model solves those problems nicely. Each spool is contained in its own roller, changing them is as easy as picking one up and setting another down, and it is the right height.

Did I mention it is the right height?!

That was the only major problem with all the other holders out there. A dry box needs the spools to be roughly in the middle of the container vertically to allow for sufficient desiccant underneath and to allow the filament to feed to the delivery tubes effectively.

As a bonus it is designed to take up very little additional horizontal space, which allows for maximum spools in your dry box space. Also, without the hangers, a much wider range of "air-tight" containers become viable for my solution.

You will need 4 608ZZ bearings for each of these you knock out. Fortunately they are very cheap! Just print off two of these kits or two plates and two of the axles and rod sets of your desired length, snap them together and you are all set.

The default kit is sized for a standard Hatchbox spool, but I will be including other axle and rod sets for other widths as I have need or get requests. (I am considering creating this as an OpenSCAD parametric project. Let me know your thoughts)

Also, don't be confused by the axle and rod set. It looks like a single piece until you finish the print and pop it apart. I was just trying to make the most efficient use of the build plate so I printed these complimentary parts as concentric cylinders.

Enjoy! and let me know your feedback. Thanks!

Printer:

monoprice maker ultimate

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

30%

Notes:

You will want to consider an extra outer perimeter or two and sufficient infill to make the axles strong enough. They are really only going to need to support 2 kg, but a little overkill is better than a failed print.

Support from the build plate is essential.

I rounded the edges on the frame posts to increase their strength. Also, I recommend printing the posts with a SOLID infill. It will work without it but if you ever want to take it apart, you stand a high chance of breaking off the posts if they are standard infill.

This is a 3D-printed base I made as a Christmas gift for a friend, which uses a NeoPixel ring and a Trinket from Adafruit to illuminate a glass Klein bottle from http://www.kleinbottle.com/. All of the electronics are integrated into a two-part 3D-printed base that can be fastened together using M3x14 screws. A spherical scallop cradles the Klein bottle, but matches the curvature of the bottle so perfectly that there is very little friction. To prevent the bottle from fall over, small dabs of hot glue are added on top of each M3 screw, holding the glass upright surprisingly well. A video of the completed piece in action can be seen at: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=YRprDHtTOR4 Photos from the assembly process can be found at: http://www.flickr.com/photos/zenwebb/sets/72157638778949224/ More photos of the completed piece can be found at: http://www.flickr.com/photos/zenwebb/sets/72157638776800776/ You can also find an article about this piece (and another gift) on my blog at: http://jason-webb.info/2013/12/glassblowing-electronics-first-commission-and-klein-bottle-gift/

Apologies in advance for the lack of very clear documentation - this was created as a one-off gift for someone, not necessarily as an easy project for anyone to make. I hope I've provided enough for you to do it anyway!

• One of each of the STLs for this Thing
  • Medium Klein bottle from http://www.kleinbottle.com/half_pint_klein.htm
  • 3 - M3x14 screws (McMaster #92005A124)
  • 3 - M3 nuts (McMaster #90592A009)
  • 4 - M2x4 screws (McMaster #92005A016)
  • 4 - M2 nuts (McMaster #90592A004)
  • NeoPixel ring (medium) (http://www.adafruit.com/products/1463)
  • 5V Trinket (http://www.adafruit.com/products/1501)

• Print out both of the STLs
  • Press fit the four M2 nuts into the four captive holes in the bottom printed piece. This may be tricky, so be careful not to strip the holes! A very small dab of glue or epoxy may be used to keep them in place, making sure not to get any in the thread.
  • Install the Trinket using the M2x4 screws, with the USB connector facing away from the base.
  • Solder wires to the +5V, GND and DIN holes of the NeoPixel ring. I recommend soldering to the top of the ring board, not the bottom.
  • Install the ring into the circular cavity of the top printed piece. You may want to lay down a little bit of hot glue to hold it firmly in place.
  • Solder the wires from the NeoPixel ring to the Trinket (5V to 5V, GND to GND and DIN to 4).
  • Press fit the three M3 nuts into the captive holes on the underside of the bottom printed piece.
  • Attach the top printed half to the bottom printed half using the three M3x14 screws, screwing into the nuts from Step 7.
  • Use hot glue to fill the holes on top of the M3x14 screws to prevent the Klein bottle from slipping.
  • Upload the "goggles_noblink" sketch from the Adafruit NeoPixel library examples to the Trinket (may need to modify to use the correct pin).
    • Photos from the assembly process can be found at: http://www.flickr.com/photos/zenwebb/sets/72157638778949224/

comments.text: This is a lovely effect and enhances the beauty of that bottle perfectly.

description.text:
This is a gauge for ensuring that you are getting the right size of Blue Swimmer Crab.

It's set for 127mm, which is correct as of the time of upload. It's worth checking that the printed item matches the specs on this page:
http://rules.fish.wa.gov.au/Species/Index/27

I like to tie the gauge to the scoop net with some flexible wire, so you can easily grab the gauge and measure the crab while it's in the metal scoop. It works well.

I am including the SCAD files so you can put in your own mounts for displays and controls. UPDATE 01/14/14

title: 3D Printer Heated Bed Power Module Mounting Brackets for the Little Driver (ANET A8, PRUSA, KOSSEL)

description.text:
Go to www.digital-sqrt.com for more information on the Little Driver Power Module.

The Little Driver Power Module is a premium heater control board with many features not found in other control boards. It can drive 30v at 30A to your heated bed or hot-end, and be controlled by and existing heated bed output or a digital signal.

The STL files are for mounting brackets. The brackets mount to 2020 or 1515 aluminum extrusions. Or if you prefer a universal bracket that can be used in just about any mounting situation.

Brackets fit both the Little Driver Ver1.5 and Ver1.9 models.

If you don't like our brackets, please check out these awesome housing by Stewart Correll
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2797455

Aug 15 - 2017: Updated mounting brackets with fan 30mm Fan mounts. We have corrected some issues with the bracket. Or apologise to those who may have printed them and found they did not work.

May 14 - 2017: Added mounting brackets with fan 30mm Fan mounts. These are a work in progress and have not been fully verified.

This is a basic ESC cover I designed for use with most ESCs sized alike DYS XM20.

This is designed to shield the zip ties from propstrikes and to stay put even if both are broken. Tighter zip ties tighten the cover. Also, they isolate the ESC from the carbon arms to eliminate shorting if you don't use heatshrink.
I use SainSmart TPU and print with no supports, vertically.
210c at 45mm/s with the bed at 70c.

remixed_from.title: E3D-v6 Dual Fan Cooling Duct for Prusa i3v

title: E3D-v6 Dual Fan Cooling Duct for Prusa i3v - dhoyt.com

description.text:
dhoyt.com

Update (04-29-2017) - Upon request I have added a mirrored STL of the original part. Body-mirroring isn't available in Fusion360 so I did the mirroring with Sketchup which is why the mirrored STL is so much larger in file size than the original.

Version 2 Upgrades:
-Mounting arm radius is smaller; snaps to E3D-v6 cooling fins better
-Added non-slip notches to mounting arms; won't slide down onto hotend during prints
-Both fans angled up to prevent the bed and part cooling prematurely
-Material cooling duct better directed towards nozzle and material extrusion area
-M3 lock-nut mounts added; no longer thread mounting bolts into plastic

Previous Version 1 - http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2191664

Thanks to ElmoC (http://www.thingiverse.com/ElmoC) for getting me to correct the orientation of the STL for print.

The MakerFarm Prusa i3v comes with a 40mm cooling fan and the E3D-v6 comes with a 30mm fan, so why not use both? This duct uses the 30mm fan to keep the hotend cool and the 40mm fan to cool the material!

Rotate the part so the mounting arm is not at an angle, the layers should be uniform vertical in the z-axis. Use ABS. PLA will be too brittle and will likely break when you snap this piece onto the E3D-v6's cooling fins.

This part has a lot of small details which may be difficult for some printers. I printed mine on a Zortrax M200 with 25 degree support material and heavy infill.

author: Madyn3D-CNC_LLC

title: Compact Microphone Pop Filter / Sound Isolator

description.text:
This is a compact microphone pop filter and sound isolator.

I designed this because I use my microphone at my desk for recording commentary and for voice chat. The pop filter I had was one of those ones that clamp on and you can bend it so it's in front of the mic, but with that, all the cables, and trying to see my monitors it became a little cumbersome.

The back 1/3rd of the casing is solid which helps to block out some background noise from my computer and when I'm typing. It works surprisingly well at isolating just my voice.

Printing the Screen
To print the filter screen you will need to make sure you turn off solid infill top and bottom. In Cura this is in Expert settings.

Use a larger number of shells to get around a 3mm border, with a .4mm nozzle a shell thickness of 3.2 works well.

Set the infill to at least 33%, the higher the infill the finer the screen will be. I have found 45% to be pretty good.

You may need to experiment a little with the layer height, fill %, and number of shells to get exactly what you want.

Microphone Dimensions
The housing of your microphone must be 44mm or less in diameter for this to work, however, this might be scaleable to work with other size microphones but the filter screen would need to be thicker so it won't rattle around.

The top part of the mic, (the metal screen around the condenser), should be around 50mm tall or less to fit under the cap.

I have two different condenser mics I use for recording audio to my computer and this fits on both, so I think that many microphones have similar dimensions and should work with this.

I would love to see if this comes in handy for anyone else. I'm really happy with how it turned out and works.

Printer:

Mod-T

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.1 - .3

Infill:

25% +

Filter Screen

Use a sharp blade or sandpaper to make sure there's no blobs or strings in the slots the screen slides into on the body and cap.

The filter screen can be trimmed with scissors if you have trouble getting it to fit into the slots in the casing and cap.

If you are using a more brittle filament than PLA to printing the filter screen you may need to warm it up in hot water before bending it so it doesn't break when putting it together.

I was a music major in college and continue to work in a career that is involved with high school marching bands all around the country.
I have always been fascinated by music and audio as well as how important sound is to creating any type of experience.
This simple device was created to easily isolate sound directly into a condenser microphone while blocking out the pops from speaking plosives as well as unwanted background noise.

A simple way to demonstrate how audio is directional as well as its ability to be reflected. Using a compatible microphone, use a computer, tape recorder, or digital audio capture device to capture someone speaking. Choose one or two test phrases to use, I suggest using the "Harvard Sentences" because they were designed specifically to test voice quality through audio devices. Harvard Sentences Record them once without the pop filter, then again with and compare the sound quality of both, including the loud "pops" from the plosives in the speech. Repeat test but this time add some sort of background noise like fans or typing on a keyboard. Experiment with microphone positioning and check the results of how well the filter blocked out background sounds.

Microphone A microphone with a housing diameter of 44mm and recording screen no taller than 50mm. Recording Equipment Other than a microphone, you will need a way to record the signal from it. Some options are a computer, tape recorder, or digital audio recorder.

• audio
  • recording
  • sound
  • electronics
  • music

description.text:
This project introduces a conceptual futuristic idea that a vacuum cleaner system is integrated into a quadcopter. Designed for Project07 of IND104 (Professor: Patty Johnson) at Syracuse University.

The model is only for showcase the concept of design. This model is NOT designed for flying.

The internal room is designed for setting 8 AA batteries, the batteries can drive/rotate the propellers, which is very interesting and cool to look at the model. The electricity wires are go through "tunnels" that connects main body and propellers. The switch on the top controls the power supply for propellers.

title: Single Piece Easy Print Zipper Pull

description.text:
I wasn't happy with the 3D printed zipper pulls I had tried because they were made with multiple parts that snapped together in some way, and would end up disconnecting after a few days of use. So, I made one that is a single piece. It's easy to print, requires no supports of any kind, and you can use just about whatever layer height you want. I do recommend setting up your slicer to print it solid with walls rather than infill. I printed one with PLA and one with PETG and they're both still going strong.

UPDATED: Now with version 2, which has a shape that is easier to get on and is slightly stronger.

A coworker asked me if I could print him a set of bridge shoes for his model train set (HO scale). He wanted to purchase a model from Shapeways, but I wanted the challenge of creating it from scratch. Here is my version of a real I-beam based rail bridge shoe. This was a somewhat challenging print, due to the overhanging top section. Originally, I designed the model without supports, and attempted to use automatic supports in my Slic3r software. This resulted in a blob of PLA, hardly resembling the original model (support washed together with the print due to the scale and was not removable). To fix this, I added three small extrusions, two underneath the top section flanges, and one underneath the top plate. Printed with 0.2 mm layers in Black PLA, this resulted in a satisfyingly realistic bridge shoe. Hope you enjoy! And, if there's other HO scale models you'd like to see, I'm always up for a challenge! Check out all my (mostly functional) designs - (https://www.thingiverse.com/bkpsu/designs) ! If you like them and want to support my hobbies (and future ideas), use one of the links below when you're planning to buy anything from these sites. Thank you in advance! Banggood: https://goo.gl/uXGg84
AliExpress: https://goo.gl/KRNurW
Amazon: https://goo.gl/nWhmjJ

My print settings (for Ultimachine Black PLA on Prusa i3 w/ E3D hotend) were as follows: 0.2mm layer height (0.2 mm first layer)
1 mm retraction
185 deg-C hotend
60 deg-C bed (glass with blue painter's tape)
Desk fan blowing at print (after first layer was down)

Finalizing your fridge magnet

Step 1: Print the model
Step 2: Sand/clean the model
Step 3: Apply glue on the magnet and not inside the model mould!
Step 4: Using large tweezers, glide and press the magnet in the hollow space.
Step 5: Flatten the glue with sandpaper after it has set.

Voila!

You are ready to roll!

description.text:
Spinner

This is a fidget spinner I made based of the design of the bio-hazard symbol. It design was inspired by that of a bio-hazard sign, in attempt to make one. The fitting of the bearings might be a hair tight, but do not worry, I assure you they fit. If anything, use some WD-40 to oil up the holes to ease popping them into place. Just remember, the easier they go in, the easier they fly

Bearing Cap

Two different variations of a bearing cap have been included with the spinner. Again, they are a tight fit, but they will go in and they will come back out. The curved design allows for better grip and control at high speeds, however it is much bulkier. The flat design is a sleek, thin design, but does not offer as much grip while spinning fast.

Curved: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2246087/
Flat: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2246094

Bearing Maintenance

Use YouTube or Google to help you find the best solution for your bearings. A general rule of thumb is to put them into a degreaser, and then re-lubricate them. Check your bearing and online to see what the recommended lubricate is.

Requires:

  • 4 608 Bearing
  • Degreaser
  • WD-40 or other bearing lubricate

Additional Files:

  1. Rounded Cap - Cap_608_Curved.stl
  2. Flat Cap - Cap_608_Flat.stl
  3. Drafix CAD File (Use With AutoCad) - SpinnerSCSO_Bio-Knockoff.dfx
  4. Wavefront 3D Object File (Use With 3D Image Editor Such As Photoshop) - SpinnerSCSO_Bio-Knockoff.obj

description.text: A filament spool holder designed around Hatchbox spools, should work with others. Easy to change and uses gravity on the cones to hold everything together. I tried to make it simple and visually appealing. The angle is easy for most printers, but with the height and overhang I had to super glue the feet down to the blue painters tape I was using after they were formed. The center piece can be used by itself if you stack up boards or about 2 filament boxes and put it in between. Print 2 of the spoolholdersides and 1 of the spoolholder. Enjoy and let me know what you think!

author: pobe1122

print_settings.Notes:: The main rotor center hub part is best printed out of PETG or nylon, which is slightly elastic and will retain the screw. I used PLA for the prototype which also works, but while PLA stronger, it will also deform more and may strip over time as it fatigues. It's imperative that the layer adhesion of the hub is good, so a slightly elevated nozzle temperature is recommended. All other parts can be made from PLA.

title: Fully Printable Collective Pitch RC helicopter.

description.text:
Disclaimer:
Be careful with high speed rotating parts. Improper printing or assembly, or inferior materials, may cause problems. Centrifugal forces of the blades will be be under 40 N at 4000 rpm, but they are not harmless if something shatters. Avoid hovering with the blades at eye level without protective goggles.

News:
I'm pretty much finished with the design. It flies great and works reliably.

News:
Changed the nose a bit. Made it narrower, and it looks a little more balanced now. The camo one pictured has the new shape. All parts should print without additional supports now.

Assembly notes:
-I attached an exploded view of the head and swash plate. The arrows marked "CA" indicate where you should use a tiny amount of CA glue (superglue/crazy glue) to bond the swash plate and bearing together.
-The main rotor head and swash plate need to be adjusted so that they operate at the same cyclic phase. This is done by turning the washout arm. If your flybarless gyro unit does not have software phase adjustment (for example KDS EBAR or Tarot ZYX S2), then your pitch links will have to run diagonally to achieve a synchronized swash plate. The prototype has a KDS EBAR V2 and flies fine with diagonal links. The Mikado mini V-Bar (and clones), BeastX and other more expensive units have swash plate phase adjustment in software, so you can do this adjustment via your computer and keep the pitch links vertical. This is preferable. I may change the design so that the servos , swashplate and head are synced mechanically, but decided against it now because it might be confusing to builders to set up.
-Install servos with thick double sided tape or hot glue. I used double sided tape for the prototype. The tabs of the recommended servos fit in the slots in the main frame. If you are using different servos you probably have to cut off the bottom tab and can install it with just hot glue.
-The clamping screws of the gear, head and shaft collar must be tightened carefully. It helps to print these parts with slightly higher temperature to ensure good layer adhesion.
-The landing gear slots into the main frame and is designed to stay locked in place, and come off in case of a crash, but the tabs will wear with frequent disassembly. I use thick CA to keep it in place after this happens.
-PLA pinions wear down relatively quickly, so it's useful if the landing gear is removeable. I might improve the solution later on. I tried Taulman 910 nylon for the pinion and it's lasting much longer now.Steel pinions are available. 13 teeth and 32p or 0.8 module will work. Axial AX30724 13T Steel Pinion Gear 32p 3mm is such a gear.
-The gear set with the large pinion will need the pinion to be installed onto the motor shaft after the motor is installed. This is because the pinion is too large to fit between the motor attachment screw holes without compromising the security of the motor installation.
-The tail rotor has to be twisted by hand after printing. You can adjust the pitch as necessary when you tune the tail.
-The tail rotor has two small holes around the hub. Insert a screw in one or both of the holes to engage with the spokes of the outrunner tail motor. Otherwise it will slip on the shaft. If the second hole doesn't line up with a spoke you can insert the second screw from the other side to act as a counterbalance so the rotor spins without vibration.

Videos:
https://youtu.be/Us8hcsxFzpM
https://youtu.be/8GmalS5hhr4
https://youtu.be/94xkn27AZd0

Required hardware:
3x75mm main shaft. Make from carbon rod or steel. No drilling required.
Two 3x6x2,5mm ball bearings for the main shaft: https://www.banggood.com/Orlandoo-F150-OH35P01-KIT-Parts-30625-Ball-Bearing-TA0009-p-985250.html?p=HD240528697332015103
Eight 2x5x2,5mm ball bearings for the blade grips.
One 10x15x4mm ball bearing for the swash plate: https://www.banggood.com/FS-Racing-FS-53910-FS-53625-6PCS-582002-Roll-Bearing-10x15x4mm-110-RC-Car-Parts-p-1153527.html?p=HD240528697332015103
Assorted #0 screws or similar self tapping 1-1,5mm diameter screws and ~6mm (~1/4") length.
Two M2x6mm screws for the main rotor blades and motor installation.
Four M2x18mm screws for the blade grips.
Four M2x10mm screws for installing the main rotor blades.
Short lengths of M2 threaded rod to hold the pitch and roll control rods together.

Servos:
https://www.banggood.com/JX-Servo-DHV56MG-5_6g-Coreless-LV-Low-Voltage-DSMG-Metal-Gear-Servo-0_89kg-0_10sec-p-1034036.html?p=HD240528697332015103
https://hobbyking.com/en_us/turnigytm-tgy-d56lv-coreless-low-voltage-ds-mg-servo-0-89kg-0-10sec-5-6g.html

Tail motor:
https://hobbyking.com/en_us/ntm-prop-drive-13-12-2400kv-40w.html

Main motor:
https://hobbyking.com/en_us/turnigy-2211-brushless-indoor-motor-2300kv.html (Needs longer shaft out the bottom end. Easy modification)
2100-3000kv motor should work fine.There are gears for two ratios in the files. The one with the small pinion fits higher kv motors. I attached photos showing how to change the shaft on typical quadcopter motors, which work great for micro helis of this size. Carbon fiber shafts are best when using PLA pinions because they don't transfer heat from the motor well, and CA sticks better to carbon fiber rods than steel shafts.

ESC:
Any small 3S capable ESC. I used 6A ESC for the tail and 10 A ESC for the main motor because that's what I had. 6A ESCs are probably enough for both motors. One ESC needs BEC, the other can be OPTO.

Battery:
3S 450mAh or similar:
https://www.banggood.com/Gaoneng-GNB-11_1V-450mAh-80160C-3S-Lipo-Battery-JSTXT30-Plug-p-1165484.html?p=HD240528697332015103
https://hobbyking.com/en_us/turnigy-nano-tech-450mah-3s-65c-lipo-e-flite-compatible-blade-180cfx-eflb4503sj30.html
The battery tray fits up to 30 mm wide batteries.

I used a KDS EBAR V2. Works well. ZYX S2, V-Bar mini or similar works just as good: https://www.banggood.com/Tarot-ZYX-S2-3-Axis-Gyro-System-ZYX23-USB-Programmer-Link-p-91613.html?p=HD240528697332015103

Notes:

Print all parts 100% infill except the body.

Body:
0% infill and one perimeter for lowest possible weight. Two perimeters is fine if your printer struggles with quality when printing just one.

Recommend printing the pinion gear from nylon, but any material will work for a while.

The main rotor center hub part is best printed out of PETG or nylon, which is slightly elastic and will retain the screw. I used PLA for the prototype which also works, but while PLA stronger, it will also deform more and may strip over time as it fatigues. It's imperative that the layer adhesion of the hub is good, so a slightly elevated nozzle temperature is recommended. All other parts can be made from PLA.

title: ARISE - a figure in response to the only artwork in space

description.text:
There is only one work of art in space. It's a 10cm (3in) aluminium human figure lying on the surface of the moon and is known as Fallen Astronaut. It was created by Belgian artist Paul Van Hoeydonck, who intended it to stand upright and be a tiny but moving tribute to the wonders and achievements of humanity. It was installed by Apollo 15 astronaut David Scott on August 1, 1971. Unknown to Van Hoeydonck, Scott lay it in the dust in front of a plaque as a monument to the 12 astronauts and cosmonauts who have died in space.  
ARISE is a work in response to the Luna statuette, a 3d printed figure which encourages the Fallen Astronaut to rise up and fulfill the destiny envisioned for it by it's creator, to stand proudly on the surface of the moon and to represent the whole of humanity. ARISE's STI file is downloadable here to create your own 3d ARISE model. The more earth-bound figures there are out in the world they more they encourage the Fallen Astronaut to ARISE.

title: Ikon Modded LG G5 Phone Case

description.text:
I added a plate made from the icon image at https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Neocatechumenal_Way - all within my slicer.

My printer is only 140mm^3, but thanks to Mr. Pythagoras, I could put it on a slant and it fits. As long as it is at more than a 45 degree angle, it will print.

I used Hatchbox TPU flexible filament, and still, it held on well even without a raft. Just needed some trimming with a razor blade at the end.

By the way, flexible filament (TPU) with this form is just a little too flexible, Re-printing with PETG (which is stiff like PLA) worked better. Still, no raft was needed, but ymmv.

title: Construction Block Raspberry Pi Zero two piece
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Updated

Two piece case for raspberry pi zero, ten by five pips long by wide, one block high. Two designs for the top and bottom, one with and one with out cutouts for the forty pin gpio.

I have not had a chance to print this out yet, as my printer is off line.

update

Corrected the spacing of everything and added features on the underside to be more consistent with the construction block system I am trying to be compatible with. Added sketchup model that was used as well as a render of what the result is with my Raspberry Pi Zero version 1.3 model in place.

Creative Commons Non Commercial Share Alike. Commercial license can be negotiated.

This is the result of having the idea of the Stemtera design bouncing around in my head. I wanted a case for the Raspberry Pi Zero that could be embedded inside of a larger construction block project with the possibility of using the GPIO of the Pi Zero.

I found a model on Thingiverse based on the construction block system and manipulated it around my existing Pi Zero model. From this I was able to determine that a final case size that was one block in height, and five by ten nobs in width and depth would be large enough to embed the Pi Zero.

Having a rough size I copy and pasted the original block out to that size, and proceeded to remove and move sections around to hollow out a space for the Pi Zero and provide access to the various ports.

I split the case into two pieces. The top is the depth of a plate, and the bottom is the depth of two plates. This allowed me to add nobs that fit in the block design language allowing the top and bottom to snap together and have a secure space for the Pi Zero to be placed.

Two different designs were created. One with access to the GPIO pins, and one without.

On the design with access to the pins, I decided to only accommodate the two by twenty pin section, and not provide access to the "Run" or "TV" pins. I like the symmetry that this allows in the final design. If anyone would like access cut out for those four pins, please leave a comment and I will add a third design..

After completing the original design, and having posted the result here, I took a closer look at the block system. My first design was naive. I copy and pasted the block around with out accounting for clearance that exists between blocks in a plain. This resulted in a design that was out over the final length by about a half a millimeter. The current design has the nobs on eight millimeter centers, and has a point one millimeter clearance around block edges. An eight by one block should fit with nominal clearance inside the hole cut out for GPIO pin access.

title: Z Axis Micrometer Endstop for Taz 4/5

description.text:
This is a variation on https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1282759 to use a slightly thicker micrometer head. The knurled portion of the Mitutoyo that I have has a diameter of 19 mm, and the mounting barrel is 10 mm long. It would not fit into piercet's part, so I created this version. The axis of the micrometer was moved 10 mm toward the center of the printer. A corresponding spacer is inserted behind the limit switch. Although the micrometer was moved 10 mm, a spacer of 8 mm works best on my machine for getting the end of the switch lever to land on the micrometer head.

The starting point for my modifications was this file: https://download.lulzbot.com/TAZ/5.0_0.5noz/production_parts/freecad/z_motor_mount-v2.1-switch-left_easy-break-ears.fcstd

Note for MOARstruder users: I have noticed that moving the z-axis limit switch out can cause interference with the fan on the MOARstruder print head when homing the x-axis. I worked around this by bending the lever on the x-axis limit switch out a few mm. Of course, by doing this, I give up a few mm of usable print volume in the x direction.

Printer Brand:

LulzBot

Printer:

TAZ 5

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.3

Infill:

85%

comments.text: Please could you use this micrometre to determine when the switch goes from ON to OFF, OFF to ON .... about 10 times, noting the values. I am interested.
comments.author: MKSA

comments.text: The switch seems to be very consistent when activated by turning the micrometer.  Here is a set of 10 open/close pairs where I read the micrometer to the nearest 0.005 mm.  Again, the switch was activated by turning the micrometer.  The z-axis remained in a fixed position during this test. The opening and closing of the switch was confirmed by checking the continuity across the leads.
comments.author: MKSA

comments.text: Quite surprising when you see the internal mechanism. The one I had supplied with the Geeetech was showing variation of close to 1/10. Anyway I replaced the mechanism (awful compared to brand like true Japanese OMRON) inside by gold plated leaf taken from old electronic equipment. Better than1/100, no hysteresis (although here not really a problem) and won't fail or wear.

author: RayLoi0721

description.text:
This 3D printed speaker is designed at the course Mechatronics Design (41030) at the Technical University of Denmark, in collaboration with Bang & Olufsen Create.

The design is trying to get the full potential out of the 3D printing technology. The speaker is designed for use in the kitchen area.

All the parts have been printed on a Ultimaker 2 printer with support from 3D Printhuset in Copenhagen, Denmark.

Visit our wordpress blog for further informationer regarding the assembling of the speaker and the project in general:

  • https://fancysocietyblog.wordpress.com/

.. or try following our guide below. Here you also find a complete "Bill Of Materials" list.

6 x M2 10 mm
6 x M2 Bolts
1 x M7 bolt
1 x Middle speaker
1 x Tweeter
1 x Rasberry Pie
1 x HiFi barry
1 x Brass top
1 x Encoder plate
1 x Encoder
1 x Skeleton
1 x Voronoi-pattern
1 x Acoustic black fabric
1 x Bottom part (five pieces)
1 x Upper shelf (for tweeter)
1 x Middle shelf (for middle speaker)
4 x Sound cable
4 x Cable clip (optional)
3 x Encoder cable
1 x Power supply
12 x Brass screws
1 x Cable sleeve

• Now we are ready, start by 3D print the parts: skeleton and voronoi-pattern.
• Laser cut parts: Encoder plate, Middle shelf, upper shelf, bottom part (5 pieces)
• Turn the brass top.
• Glue the laser cutted middle part into the brass top
• Make the bottom: glue the five laser cutted pieces together. The solid part at the bottom,
three circles in the middle and the top part with the screw holes on top.
• Paint the bottom part
• Sew the audio fabric in to a cone.
• Solder the encoder with wires on the three legs (make sure that the wires are a female-
socket at the other end) and the speaker clips on to the speaker wire.
• Sew the fabric on to the voronoi-pattern and make a hole in the middle.
• Place the encoder in the voronoi-pattern by letting in through the top hole of the voronoi-
pattern and through the textile. Fasten the encoder to the voronoi-pattern-pattern with
an M7-bolt.
• Place the voronoi-pattern part on the skeleton
• Glue the textile to the bottom of the voronoi-pattern inner side.
• Assemble the tweeter to the upper shelf with two M3-screws ands bolts. Make sure that
the wires from the encoder go through the hole in the upper shelf.
• Screw the tweeter assembly to the skellaton with 4 brass screws.
• Attach the speaker cables to the tweeter
• Assemble the middle speaker to the middle shelf with four M3-screws and bolts. Make
sure that the wires from the encoder and tweeter go through the hole in the middle shelf.
• Attach the speaker cables to the middle speaker and put them through the hole in the
middle shelf (remember which set of cables go to which speaker).
• Screw the middle speaker assembly to the skeleton with 4 brass screws.
• Plug the Wi-Fi-module to the raspberry pie in the left top USB-port.
• Screw the Rasberry pie at the bottom with two brass-screws (make sure that there is
enough space for the Wi-Fi module and power.
• Plug the wires from the tweeter to the left speaker gate and the wires from the middle
speaker to the right speaker gate. The encoder should go in pin number 14, 16 and 18
starting from the left of the counter.
• Put the cable sleeve onto the power supply cable.
• Insert the power supply to the HiFiBerry.
• Attach the HiFiBerry to the Rasberry pie (use the screws that comes with the HiFiBerry).
• Screw the bottom to the skeleton-pattern with four brass screws.
• Place the brass top on the encoder.
• Connect your device to the speaker and listen to some dope music!

author: Johny601

title: Wrap It Up Box from Chappelle's Show

description.text:
One of my favorite Chappelle's Show sketches was the "wrap it up box"... I make a lot of references to it to co-workers, so when I got my 3D printer, one of the first things I designed was this replica wrap it up box.  
I tried to make it as accurate to scale as possible from the limited number of pictures/video... but obviously it's not that important to have a perfect replica.  The print pictured is at scaled 50%.  
You'd better wrap that gavel up, "B"!

Print with fill enabled.  The speaker section is actually just recessed in the model, so the fill gives it the different texture.  Use a black sharpie to color the speaker grille.  
Print the wrap it up text page and cut/tape the appropriate size text into your box.  Insert a red button into the top hole (I used a red plastic bead).  
The back simply snaps into place.  There is plenty of space inside to add electronics, if you'd like to make a functional wrap it up box.  At 100%, the hole is designed for a 1/4" panel mounted button.

Update 2017-04-07:
OpenSCAD files uploaded.

Update 2017-04-09:
Proper F2.STL file has been uploaded.

NB: Not all STL files shown as preview icons!

This is my winter project. "Project Modular Aircraft" or just PMA.
Idea was to create a model which relatively simple to modify by adding or removing modules. Pusher propeller configuration for potential FPV use. Dual tail booms for lighter version.

Currently I'm still working on User Manual as project pretty complex. Draft version has been uploaded.

In addition I'll provide all source code "as is" without warranty.
Source OpenSCAD files will be uploaded "as is" later on. Experienced developers will be able to modify aircraft as they like.

Due to bad weather I didn't maiden it yet. But it's 100% ready for it.

description.text:
English translation further down.

Aide au maintien d'un crayon

Cette aide technique permet à un enfant de maintenir un crayon en serrant le support dans son poing, à l'horizontale. Le pas de vis permet d'inclure tout type de crayon à l'intérieur du support sans risque pour l'enfant.

L'utilisation du plugin Surfaces floues de Cura permet d'avoir un état de surface rugueux en contact avec la main de l'enfant, ce qui permet de mieux maintenir la main sans blesser l'utilisateur.

Créée au RehabLab du CMRRF de Kerpape (Bretagne, France), avec l'aide d'ergothérapeutes.
Plus d'informations sur le site.

Pen holder for children

This Thing is a technical aid created at the CMRRF de Kerpape (France). It aims to help children who cannot hold a pen between their fingers. Children can use this device to draw, holding the device in their palm as shown in the picture above.

Every type of pen can be inserted into this technical aid thanks to a screw thread which hold the pen still.

The Fuzzy Skin Cura plugin can be used to improve the stability of the device without hurting the child.

Designed with the help of occupational therapists, at the RehabLab. More information on this website.

description.text:
This is for my breakfast boiled eggs. I have a big salt jar in the kitchen but needed something more precise for the table.

So I made this, it has a simple shape, and the aperture is just big enough to allow a few grains to trickle out. Perfect for my breakfast boiled eggs, perfect if you're trying to reduce your sodium intake.

Printer:

Anet A8

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.1mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

I printed this in PLA on a glass bed, extruder 200°C, bed 60°C.

Assembly

After printing, you'll probably find the stopper is a bit tight, don't force it, work it in and out a few times and it will eventually turn all the way freely.

I used Fusion 360, sketched a simple conic curve, revolved 360°. Extruded a base with a 15mm hole, made a thread in it, M15x1mm. Then a 2mm hole on centre, all the way though so the salt can get out (very important!).

Then I sketched a 15mm diameter circle and extruded it to make the plug, threaded it same as the hole.

A few chamfers and fillets and it's ready to print.

author: sennaverhey

description.text:
English translation further down.

Support de paille

Certains handicaps empêchent les personnes d'utiliser leurs membres. En particulier, il est difficile pour eux de tenir un verre, et la simple action de boire devient compliquée. Pour remédier à cela, ils disposent en général de verres comportant une paille. En s'approchant du verre, ils attrapent la paille avec la bouche, puis peuvent boire le contenu du verre. Toutefois, la paille est peu stable dans le verre. Quand il est plein, la paille remonte, voire tombe, et alors la personne est dans l'incapacité de boire, ce qui est problématique si personne n'est là pour l'aider. De même, la paille part vers le côté quand on essaie de la prendre avec la bouche, ce qui est assez frustrant.

Cette aide technique se fixe à un verre, puis la paille est insérée dans le trou prévu à cet effet. Le porte paille existe en deux versions : une version plus enfantine, en forme de baleine, et une version pour les plus grands, plus fonctionnelle. Grâce au support de paille, la paille ne risque plus de tomber ou de partir quand on essaie de l'attraper. Un petit objet, mais un grand pas vers l'autonomie.

Créé au RehabLab du CMRRF de Kerpape (Bretagne, France), avec l'aide d'ergothérapeutes. Plus d'informations sur le site.

Straw holder

Some people have difficulties to move their arms, and this kind of disability can be annoying for even the simplest of action. For instance, they need someone to help them in order to drink. A way to drink without external help is the use of a straw in a glass. However, straws have a tendency to fall from full glasses, and to escape from the approaching mouth of a thirsty person.

Thanks to this device, a straw can be fixed on a glass, preventing falls and uncontrolled movements of the straw. As small as an object it may be, it is a great step toward achieving autonomy for disabled people.

Designed with the help of occupational therapists, at the RehabLab of the CMRRF of Kerpape (France). More information on this website.

description.text:
I designed this refractor telescope to fit a 63mm diameter, 500mm focal length lens. Because of the size, the tube is divided into 4 main 100mm parts, with one of them containing a dovetail for fixation. The focuser is made for 1.25" eyepieces. I later made an adapter to fit the focuser from ANicolai: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2130522, because the helicoidal focuser introduced to many virbations, especially at high magnification (end_tube2 and porte_occ2.

I used part of the threading library from Trevor Moseley (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:27183).

Printer:

Tronxy X1

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

20

Notes:

Mostly 0.2 mm layer height, except for the main tubes, where i went 0.3mm for the main section. The main point of concern is to have a perfect bed adhesion (with raft or not) to ensure that the parts will assemble in a straight tube at the end. Support were used for the end part (the focuser one).

Avoid printing with transparent or semi-transparent PLA (had to use the blue one, which is semi-transparent). This cause some residual light to get to the eyepiece.

author: WRonX

title: Fidget Cube 2.0

description.text:
Meet Fidget Cube 2.0

What I have done is recreate the fidget cube in Autodesk Fusion 360 to reduce the price point from $13 USD to only a few dollars.

Feel free to comment if you have any suggestions!

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator (5th Generation)

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

No

Infill:

100%

Notes:

The get the best results, you should use PLA filament. When the PLA is mixed with flexible filament, the different forces cause the cube and it's parts to break apart. It is possible to print using flexible filament, but the fidget cube will not retrain is strength, the parts will not remained attached or in their original shapes. I have not yet tested it with ABS or with Carbon Fiber. The flexible filament I used when testing it was manufactured my M3D. If you are looking to purchase it, they call it their Tough Filament.
I recommend that when you do print the Fidget Cube, either print the entire cube plus all of it parts as one using the Fidget Cube 2.0 file, or use the separate files that will be uploaded soon. When using the separate files, print the main cube and and the outer shell of the cube in one color of filament and print the inner parts of the cube in a different color.

Assembly

How to assembly your Fidget Cube 2.0

Step 1: Insert/Snap in place all of the small pieces into their appropriate placing on the cube.
Step 2: Side by side, find the outer shell piece that matches the side of the cube you are currently on.
Step 3: After locating that piece, align the pegs on the shell to the holes in the cube and snap together.
Step 4: If you desire, you can put a dab of glue on each peg to keep the outer shell in place without the option to remove it. I highly DO NOT recommend this because if a piece breaks, you will have to re-print the entire cube.

NOTE: Someone pointed out to me today that when they printed their cube, the two small gears fell out of their holes. I am currently working on a fix for this, but in the meantime, you can take a small and thin piece of wire and string it through the small hole on the maze side of the cube and on the switch side of the cube through the hole in each of the gears. That should fix the problem until I finish working and testing a fix for the problem.

Design

The Fidget Cube 2.0 was sculpted entirely using Autodesk Fusion 360 and Blender.

Need for a Fidget Cube What are Fidget Cubes? A Fidget Cube is a cube designed for kids that always are in a need of doing something, wether that be flicking a pencil of tapping on a desk. What the Fidget Cube does is re-create the idea of fidgeting. Instead of annoying everyone around you be flicking or tapping something, the idea was to create a silent fidget device. Ultimately, this failed because Fidget Cubes on the market today still make noise, causing some people to become off-task because of the distraction. How does that change with the Fidget Cube 2.0? Not only is the Fidget Cube 2.0 completely silent, except for the few occasional times when something is misplaced and it rubs against the cube, the Fidget Cube 2.0 also gives people a opportunity to discover what is inside their fidget device.

Activity So, you may be wondering how to make this integrate into your class lesson plan. Well, the Fidget Cube 2.0 was designed with teachers, students, and people in mind. One of my personal favorite example is how part of the Fidget Cube 2.0 can be used to demonstrate the use of levers. On the side of the cube that you attach the switch to, you will see a small rod that the switch attaches to. You could discuss with your students what would be the results of the switch and its motion if the rod had been placed differently. You could discuss it in the terms of 1st, 2ed, and 3ed degree levers. If you have any other questions about how you could use this in your classroom, please feel free to message me!

Materials When printing this, I recommend that for the classroom to use PLA filament. Remember, because you need to print the cube and all of its parts with 100% infill, I would recommend that if printing more than 1 not to skimp on the filament.
In you are using this for High School and or Higher Education, I would recommend to print it in both PLA and FLEXIBLE filament and mix them together to create different combinations. An example of this would be to print the cube using the flexible filament and the parts using the PLA. This is a great experiment to do if you are going to be studying and analyzing force and Newton's Laws of Motion.

Prep When printing in a classroom setting, I would recommend that you have at least 1 Fidget Cube 2.0 already printed and made so the kids can see and get a feel for what they are going to be printing. Please let me know if you use this in your classroom and how you used it and if you have any idea about how to make it better by private messaging me!

If you have a thin piece of wire, you can cut it to fit in the holes to help hold the gears in. I will make sure that in the fixes I am currently making to the cube that this problem is fixed. title: Mantis Stereo Microscope 1" Loupe Lens adapter

description.text:
I picked up a Vision Engineering Mantis Stereo Microscope a couple months ago.  I do a lot of soldering of really small components, so this is really nice for soldering and inspection.  The Mantis is really cool with a large open face, rather than small eyepieces, but still has two optical paths for stereo vision (and you can move your head a bit to look around).  I got a great deal on it, but it came with no lenses... and even used chipped original lenses sell for ~$150, so I decided to make my own, using lenses from cheap jeweler's loupes I had laying around.  
These jeweler's loupes have 1" glass lenses, and sell on ebay for ~$6 shipped for a set of 4.  Of course, you could use higher quality lenses if you have some, but the quality is actually pretty good from these.  
I don't know whether the loupes are exaggerating their magnification, if they perform differently because of the Mantis optics, or if 'x' magnification even has a standard... but I compared these lenses to the specs given in the Mantis manual for the original lenses and determined that the "2.5x" is equivalent to 2x, "5x" is equivalent to 3x, "7.5x" is equivalent to 4x, and "10x" is equivalent to 6x.  The lens_specs.txt file has the working distance, field of view, and depth of field specs from the manual.  
The Mantis can have two lenses mounted at once.  The original lenses from 4x-10x are parfocal, meaning that you can switch between any two lenses and you won't have to move the head to refocus.  In my case, I liked the 3x for normal work, and 6x for close-up work, so I used the 3x lens in the short one, and made the 6x the correct length to be parfocal with the short 3x.  
I also included the ability to "stack" a lens on the 6x, so when I need REALLY close up, I can stack the 4x on the 6x and get 10x.  Of course this is no longer parfocal, the quality suffers a little bit from using two lenses, and the working distance gets pretty close, but it works for the times that you really need to look up close.  
For attaching to the microscope... rather than trying to screw on the original threads, I noticed that there were flat spots on the sides of the threads, so I also made the adapter round with flat spots.  This let me pop the adapter straight up in place, and lock it in with a quarter turn (so the flat spot is grabbing the threads).  The end of the long adapter, as well as the additional stacking adapter, are both oval shaped.  This lets the adapter pop in place and lock with a quarter turn as well.  The long adapter is tapered so it doesn't block light from the halogen lights at the focal point, even with the higher magnification attachment.

I'd recommend first printing the short adapter (loupe_lens_adapter_short.stl) and verify fit (much quicker than printing the long one).  You may need to slightly tweak the X and Y scale to get a snug fit, depending on your microscope and printer.  
Once you print the parts, you need to extract the lenses from the plastic loupe housings.  On most of mine, I was able to simply press them out (push from the top out the bottom).  One was glued in pretty well though, so I used wire cutters to break the plastic and pop the lens out.  
The lenses may snap right in place on the printed adapters, though my lens sizes varied from 0.93" to 1.0", so some fit better than others.  A small dab of glue, epoxy, etc. will hold it in place just fine.  
Once the lenses are in place, simply install the adapter on your microscope and enjoy!

comments.text: As the lenses you are using have a smaller diameter than the original lenses, how does that effect the actual field of view?
comments.author: Wookbert

comments.text: There's no loss of FOV, since only a portion of the lens is really used.  You can test this by looking through the microscope with the lens in your hand, and see how far away you can move it before you lose FOV (it's pretty far).
comments.author: Wookbert

comments.text: I wonder whether one could build this using either serious, but cheap, second hand camera objectives or affordable accessory lenses for compact cameras from ebay, and thus get better visual quality. Problem is that I have virtually no clue about optics.
